    Beta-Binomial model for schnapps

    BetaBinom.Rmd
    library(schnapps)

    Background

    This vignette demonstrates how to use a beta-binomial model instead of a binomial model for the HMM emission model.

    Inference

    data("haplotypes")
data("CNbins")
haplotypes <- format_haplotypes_dlp(haplotypes, CNbins)
hscn <- callHaplotypeSpecificCN(CNbins, haplotypes, likelihood = "binomial")

print(hscn)
#> Haplotype specific copy number object 
#>  
#> Number of cells: 250
#> Bin size: 0.5 Mb 
#> Inferred LOH error rate: 0.018 
#> Emission model for HMM: binomial 
#> Average distance from median to expected BAF = 0.0025 
#> Average ploidy = 4 
#> Average number of segments = 79

hscn_bb <- callHaplotypeSpecificCN(CNbins, haplotypes, likelihood = "betabinomial")
#> VGLM    linear loop  1 :  loglikelihood = -313107.6487
#> VGLM    linear loop  2 :  loglikelihood = -309166.851
#> VGLM    linear loop  3 :  loglikelihood = -308616.1066
#> VGLM    linear loop  4 :  loglikelihood = -308589.8552
#> VGLM    linear loop  5 :  loglikelihood = -308589.4503
#> VGLM    linear loop  6 :  loglikelihood = -308589.4464
#> VGLM    linear loop  7 :  loglikelihood = -308589.4464

print(hscn_bb)
#> Haplotype specific copy number object 
#>  
#> Number of cells: 250
#> Bin size: 0.5 Mb 
#> Inferred LOH error rate: 0.018 
#> Emission model for HMM: betabinomial 
#>   Inferred over dispersion: 0.0096
#>   Tarones Z score: 180.868
#> Average distance from median to expected BAF = 0.0026 
#> Average ploidy = 4 
#> Average number of segments = 79

    We see that the model inferred a modest degree of overdispersion in the data, but that this was siginificantly different from 0 dispersion (Tarones Z-score is high).

    Below I’ll plot the heatmaps for the two output, which in this case are very similar.

    Binomial model

    plotHeatmap(hscn, plotcol = "state_BAF", plottree = FALSE, spacer_cols = 15)

    Beta-Binomial model

    plotHeatmap(hscn_bb, plotcol = "state_BAF", plottree = FALSE, spacer_cols = 15)

    QC plot

    To interrogate the difference between the binomial and beta-binomial models we can plot the BAF and overlay the two models.

    plotBBfit(hscn_bb)

    We can check how similar the results are by comparing the two dataframes. We find for this data that the results are very similar.

    print(dim(hscn$data))
#> [1] 1076252      19
print(dim(hscn_bb$data))
#> [1] 1076261      19
all.equal(orderdf(hscn$data), orderdf(hscn_bb$data))
#>  [1] "Attributes: < Component \"row.names\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ >"               
#>  [2] "Component \"chr\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"            
#>  [3] "Component \"chr\": 31148 string mismatches"                                                        
#>  [4] "Component \"start\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                   
#>  [5] "Component \"end\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                     
#>  [6] "Component \"cell_id\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"        
#>  [7] "Component \"cell_id\": 1348 string mismatches"                                                     
#>  [8] "Component \"state\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                   
#>  [9] "Component \"copy\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                    
#> [10] "Component \"alleleA\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                 
#> [11] "Component \"alleleB\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                 
#> [12] "Component \"totalcounts\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                             
#> [13] "Component \"BAF\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                     
#> [14] "Component \"state_min\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                               
#> [15] "Component \"Maj\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                     
#> [16] "Component \"Min\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"                                     
#> [17] "Component \"state_AS_phased\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"
#> [18] "Component \"state_AS_phased\": 144149 string mismatches"                                           
#> [19] "Component \"state_AS\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"       
#> [20] "Component \"state_AS\": 130654 string mismatches"                                                  
#> [21] "Component \"LOH\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"            
#> [22] "Component \"LOH\": 50900 string mismatches"                                                        
#> [23] "Component \"phase\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"          
#> [24] "Component \"phase\": 75752 string mismatches"                                                      
#> [25] "Component \"state_phase\": Lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ (string compare on first 1076252)"    
#> [26] "Component \"state_phase\": 94135 string mismatches"                                                
#> [27] "Component \"state_BAF\": Numeric: lengths (1076252, 1076261) differ"

    Another thing we can check is the total number of segments identified by the HMM. Using the beta-binomial model should reduce the influence of any noisy regions and thus we might expect fewer segments. We do observe fewer segments in the beta-binomial model.

    segs <- create_segments(hscn$data, field = "state_AS_phased")

segs_bb <- create_segments(hscn_bb$data, field = "state_AS_phased")

print(dim(segs))
#> [1] 38788     5
print(dim(segs_bb))
#> [1] 35084     5

    Summary

    With this dataset, the difference between the nbinomial model and beta-binomial model is minimal but produces a statistically superior fit, in lower quality datasets with for example lower depth of coverage the beta-binomial model may may provide more noticeable differences.
